title: Married in two different countries to two different women
question: I was married in California to my U.S. citizen wife in 2004. I got deported from the U.S. in 2006 and had no contact with my wife. In 2010 I married a woman in Argentina. Now I have finally been able to contact my wife and speak with her. I am planning on filing a divorce from her in California. My questions are: 1) What happens to my marriage in Argentina? 2) Does me getting married in Argentina affect my divorce in California as far as assets and child custody? There are assets in my marriage and I want to know if I loose them because I got married in Argentina. Thank you for any help!!
question_tags: Divorce,Contested divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Immigration,Deportation,Child custody,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt
answers:
Under California law, your most recent marriage is not valid. The state will not recognize it. This can cause some serious problems, such as if you have health insurance for your "spouse" (recent case I consulted on). You really need to get this all resolved. As for items assets you have accumulated during your current union, you will have to disclose all CURRENT assets and debts to process your divorce, but the court's primary focus are the assets and debts that existed as of the date of separation (although there are some exceptions that apply). Without more information about your situation, it is difficult to give a proper analysis of your situation. There may be complications that have to be addressed sooner rather than later; or, it may be a fairly simple process.

You do have options. This does not have to be a long, expensive, drawn out, contested battle. If you and your wife (the first) can resolve everything with each other, through a mediator, or some other out-of-court, problems solving process, you will be far better off in terms of being able to move on with your life with your current relationship.

I strongly recommend that you consult an attorney as soon as possible.

I hope this information was helpful to you. If you would like more information, there are local workshops for couples looking to divorce peacefully and out-of-court. I have included a link for you to look into that. There is also a great deal of information on my web site.

Good luck.

I'm not an expert in Argentine matrimonial law (I don't know if there's one on Avvo) but, at least under the law of the 50 states, your second marriage isn't a valid marriage; you were still married to wife #1, who was and is still alive. Deportation isn't a divorce. Your "marriage" in Argentina has no effect on your marriage or divorce in California; however, your second wife may have all sorts of legal rights against you in Argentina, if you told her you were legally able to marry her.
